nodes.bodyText: I would expect this file in the src/main/resources?
That's a bit emberrassing, but I couldn't figure out how to reference the relative path to another folder within the JAR file when reading the file's contents... So I opted for the easy way 😄

If you keep the same directoy path in the resources directory it will work the same as when put in the java directory. The compilation process compiles everything to the same directory anyway. So please do move this file to src/main/resources/org/openhab/binding/modbus/helioseasycontrols/internal.
Thanks for the hint, works like a charm 👌
Switch item-type doesn't support state options. Please remove or change to Number (although Switch seems more logical here).

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway.
+See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing               | Description                                                |
+|---------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the [Modbus documentation](https://www.openhab.org/addons/bindings/modbus/).
+Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device.
+The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample.
+It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+
+## Channels
+
+The following channels are supported:
+
+| Channel                          | Channel Group   | Description                                                                                                                      | Item Type                | RW | 
+| -------------------------------- | --------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------ | -- | 
+| sysdate                          | general         | The KWL's system date and time                                                                                                   | DateTime                 | RW | 
+| summerWinter                     | general         | Indicates if summertime or wintertime is active (OFF = wintertime, ON = summertime)                                              | Switch                   | RW | 
+| autoSwUpdate                     | general         | Indicates if automatic software updates are enable                                                                               | Switch                   | RW | 
+| accessHeliosPortal               | general         | Indicates if access to Helios portal is enabled                                                                                  | Switch                   | RW | 
+| minFanStage                      | unitConfig      | Minimum fan stage (0 or 1) (0, 1)                                                                                                | Number                   | RW | 
+| preHeaterStatus                  | general         | Pre-Heater Status                                                                                                                | Switch                   | RW | 
+| humidityControlSetValue          | humidityControl | Humidity control set value (in percent) (20 - 80 %)                                                                              | Number:Dimensionless     | RW | 
+| humidityControlSteps             | humidityControl | Humidity control steps (in percent) (5 - 20 %)                                                                                   | Number:Dimensionless     | RW |

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway.
+See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing               | Description                                                |
+|---------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the [Modbus documentation](https://www.openhab.org/addons/bindings/modbus/).
+Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device.
+The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample.
+It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```

nodes.bodyText: You could consider ModbusBitUtilities utility function to parse string, perhaps it does the same thing you do here?
Should you convert ZonedDateTime to helios system time zone before extracting dayOfMonth etc?
I don't think this is necessary for setting the bypass' from and to date. These settings are independent from the actual system time.

Let me try to make point in a different way
Surely you agree that 2020-01-02 01:00 UTC and 2020-01-01 23:00 UTC-2h represent exactly same moment in time?
Just extracting the date from "local dates" yields different results.

Yes, I'm aware of the GMT offset having an impact on the day in the date. But in this specific case (setting the bypass date) I don't see the relevance.
The user, a rule, etc. wants to change the day from which on the bypass functionality should be active or deactivated. This will result in a date with its day and month based on the local time zone being assigned to an item. Now I grab precisely this day and month and write this to the device.
Maybe I'm missing something, but in this case I'm just using the DateTime type as a vehicle to get month and day set together. Please also see the private class BypassDate for my internal representation which is completely independent of any time zone.

I see what you are saying but I think you are missing my point.
I will try describe the whole flow and why I think you should consider taking zones into account
Given

user with local time zone UTC -6. User has configured openhab correctly that it uses this timezone. Ui elements etc use UTC -6
Helios with UTC timezone

Now, user open openhab ui and sets bypass date to Jan 02.
Currently binding writes Jan 02 to Helios. Helios interprets Jan 02 date against its system time of course. So bypass mode gets actually activated Jan 02 00:00 UTC, which corresponds to Jan 01 18:00 in UTC-6.
So as summary user thought he set bypass to Jan 2 (his time) but it is actually Jan 1 (his time)
I might be missing something as well but hopefully the above opens up my thinking

I think I get your point. However, if the user used the device's own configuration web interface and set the date there, the result would be the same. In the end the device will use its own system time to activate/deactivate the bypass.
After all, it's more important that the settings in the device according to its local time zone are correct. The bypass depends both on a period of time in which it will be considered as well as on the outside and room temperature. So this is something very local and quite dpendent on the local time as well.
So even if it were a valid use case that I run an OH instance in Austria to control a ventilation system in the US, I would, as a user, still want to set the bypass to a specific date, when I want the bypass to become active in the US, not having to consider possible time zone differences.
I know it's only one line of code, but I'm still not convinced 😉

+# Modbus.HeliosEasyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+This implementation was done for my personal use for a KWL EC 500W L device.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+A Helios Ventilation device can be added either manually in Paper UI or via a `.things` file via a Modbus Bridge providing the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Modbus.HeliosEasyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+This implementation was done for my personal use for a KWL EC 500W L device.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+A Helios Ventilation device can be added either manually in Paper UI or via a `.things` file via a Modbus Bridge providing the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```

+# Modbus.HeliosEasyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+This implementation was done for my personal use for a KWL EC 500W L device.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+A Helios Ventilation device can be added either manually in Paper UI or via a `.things` file via a Modbus Bridge providing the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

How do you want to handle the timezones? For example, should the binding write dates as UTC to the device?
If I understood correctly, the current implementation ignores the time zone all together

The device has separate variables for date and time as well as for the difference to GMT / UTC.
This method only takes care of the date part.
I'm not sure it's actually necessary to consider the time zone here - do you think there is a use case for this?

Yes, when writing ZonedDateTime it can be in whatever timezone really. E.g. If it comes from persistence, the time zone might be UTC or might be local, dependending on implementation details.
What should matter is the instant represented by the object.
It would be a different story if we would be dealing with "naive" datetime objects which does not have a concept of timezone.
Two approaches come to mind:

write both the timezone and time part. One could convert ZonedDateTime to local time zone first to avoid any funny time zones ending up to the device
convert ZonedDateTime to local time zone (system default), ignore the timezone and write only the time part

What do you think?
I guess you could also read the timezone of the device and convert ZonedDateTime to that
@bern77 did you find some goo way to resolve this?

I think so, I'm now using a single DateTime item and set all 3 paramets (date, time and GMT offset) in one go.
Also, I've added an Action to set the device's system time to the server system time.
This is now assuming system default timezone... Is that what you want?

Here dateTime would only contain a date, no time information. So I think it should be fine.
See above - the protocol spec splits up date and time into different variables... so I believe the current implementation should be fine.
It would be more elegant though if I created a method to set date, time and difference to UTC at the same time...

Did you find some good resolution here @bern77 ?

It's great that user can refresh the data on demand. Unfortunately, I think openHAB commands all channels REFRESH on startup, generating a lot of traffic since there are so many channels.
One way to handle this is to throttle refreshes. See FMI weather binding as one example https://github.com/openhab/openhab-addons/blob/2.5.x/bundles/org.openhab.binding.fmiweather/src/main/java/org/openhab/binding/fmiweather/internal/AbstractWeatherHandler.java
readValue uses the locking mechanism, so the traffic communicating with the device is handled in a controlled way. Or do you mean traffic in general?

I think it would mean all these commands would pile up in queue of sort (=waiting for the lock), executed in very rapid fashion.
In my experience with other bindings it makes the openHAB itself slow (raspberry pi) since so many state updates are fired... Naturally after this initialization things are running smoothly again. So it's not a dealbreaker, just inconvenience
You are correct that locking ensures that at most one transaction is running at the same time. But still the rate of the requests is quite high. The rate is limited by the parameters set in the tcp thing.
Writing this I realized that data is read by one variable at a time, not as one chunk. So actually my advice of throttling (I.e. Refreshing only if last refresh for the thing is old enough) does not make sense -- only way to refresh all the N channels is to fire N requests?
Here are instructions how to test it if you like:

create things
link all channels
start openHAB, observe if there are requests flying to the device (e.g. via logs). Check long it takes to update all channels

I believe channels might get REFRESH when the things or items are recreated. This happens when the thigns/items files are modified.

Exactly, the process is to write the variable number to a register and retrieve data from the register in return. Variable by variable.
At the moment the implementation will fetch all variables each refresh interval; one improvement could be to only fetch variables that are actually tied to an item. But so far when testing I didn't experience any particular delays (at least on my PC as well as on the Linux server running my PROD instance). Sure, some variable will take a little while to show a value in the sitemap, but I personally didn't mind so far...
Yeah I would keep it simple if it performs "well enough".

Actually, ignore my last statement 😂
I'm already just fetching the variables linked to an item...
Thinking about it, I'm wondering if simply introducing an additional delay before unlocking after a read transaction would have the same result as the throttling mechanism...
Btw. your choice of variable name for the throttling is quite amusing for an Austrian 😉 (cf. https://www.dict.cc/german-english/Fut.html)

I don't think it is a good idea to introduce any delays in Helios binding, after all delays are ensured by the transport bundle. Specifically, timeBetweenTransactionsMillis parameter of tcp thing is already ensuring delays between transactions.
What I meant with throttling (as implemented in FMI weather) is slightly different. Instead of processing all refresh commands, we would wait for a while, e.g. 3 seconds, and combine all incoming refresh commands in this interval together and just make one operation to refresh the data.
The main use case with FMI is to make it more efficient to update the data when many/all channels receive the refresh command. Generic modbus binding has similar technique although implementation is quite different
The end result is quite different from a simple delay since we limit the amount of transactions.
However, with Helios each channel corresponds to one write/read transaction, and similar optimization is not possible. I guess the best thing you can do is handle only the linked channels 🙂
Good to know about the fut 😅

Thanks, then I'll leave the implementation as it is. If some users do experience issues I can still revisit this. But I wouldn't expect it to be honest.
Glad I could help with my little 'lesson in Austrian' 😁

@@ -0,0 +1,306 @@
+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

It's also part of the device's Modbus protocol specification. As far as I can tell this it what the devices integrated web based config app uses to log out the user from the web page. I'm actually not sure if it makes a lot of sense in the binding.
Probably it can be removed...

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+
+## Channels

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

nodes.bodyText:
To be perfectly honest, I'm not really sure what this does exactly. The documentation doesn't really provide any details on this and the devices web interface (which is also based on the Modbus implementation) doesn't seem to support this as far as I could see.
You're probably right that this would also make sense as an Action.

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.

+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
+

+# Helios easyControls Binding
+
+Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices use a Modbus protocol to communicate with different sensors, switches, etc. Some devices come with an integrated web interface (easyControls) as well as a Modbus TCP/IP Gateway. See https://www.easycontrols.net/de/service/downloads/send/4-software/16-modbus-dokumentation-f%C3%BCr-kwl-easycontrols-ger%C3%A4te for the corresponding specification.
+
+## Supported Things
+
+| Thing                           | Description                                                |
+|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
+| helios-ventilation-easycontrols | Helios Heat-Recovery Ventilation devices with easyControls |
+
+## Configuration
+You first need to set up a Modbus bridge according to the Modbus documentation. Things in this extension will use the selected bridge to connect to the device. The configuration of a Helios Ventilation device via a `.things` file would look like the following code sample. It's required to provide the device's IP address, port and unit ID (port and unit ID cannot be changed and always have to be 502 and 180; in fact the values provided here are ignored by the binding and the fixed values 502 and 180 are used):
+```
+Bridge modbus:tcp:modbus-gateway "Modbus TCP/IP Gateway" [ host="x.x.x.x", port=502, id=180, enableDiscovery=true ] {
+    Thing helios-ventilation-easycontrols kwl "KWL"
+}
+```
